title: Lagarde gets lawmakers’ backing for top job at ECB
text:
President-designate of the European Central Bank Christine Lagarde speaks during a meeting at the EU Parliament in Brussels on September 4, 2019 | John Thys/AFP via Getty Images Lagarde gets lawmakers’ backing for top job at ECB

Christine Lagarde on Wednesday won the support of EU lawmakers to become the next president of the European Central Bank.

Parliamentarians in the legislature’s Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) backed Lagarde after a two and a half hour hearing in Brussels, as part of the nomination process for the ECB’s top job.

MEPs backed Lagarde in a secret ballot, with 37 lawmakers voting in favor and 11 against, while four abstained.

“I am delighted to see a woman of Christine Lagarde’s experience and ability nominated to this job and I wish her good luck with it,” said liberal MEP Luis Garicano, who works as the whip for Renew Europe in ECON. “I have no doubt she will be a powerful voice at the helm of the ECB and she has my full confidence.”

The full European Parliament is scheduled to formalize ECON’s opinion during the week of September 16 in Strasbourg. Parliament’s opinion is nonbinding but seen as a politically necessary step for the appointment.

Following the plenary vote, EU leaders are set to officially unveil Lagarde as the next ECB boss when they meet in Brussels in October for a summit. ECB President Mario Draghi steps down on October 31, when his eight-year term comes to an end.

ECON on Wednesday also backed ECB Executive Board Member Yves Mersch to become the vice chair of the central bank’s supervisory board in Frankfurt. Mersch secured 35 votes in favor of his nomination, 14 against and four abstentions.

The opinion on Mersch will also need rubberstamping in the plenary later this month.
